intro: Calandrinia polypetala var. composita, commonly known as the desert morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Portulacaceae family and is characterized by its fleshy, succulent leaves and vibrant pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils and full sun. Its flowers open in the morning and close by midday, a trait that gives it its common name. The species is often cultivated for its ornamental value and drought tolerance.
